description: From Middle English ferten, farten, from Old English feortan, from Proto-Germanic *fertanÄ…, from Proto-Indo-European *perd-.
The noun is from Middle English fert, fart, from the verb.

entries.meaning: (informal) An emission of digestive gases from the anus; a flatus. [from 15th c.]
examples: I think I heard a fart. Was it you, Nigel?
Silent farts are often the smelliest.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, impolite, derogatory) An irritating person; a fool.
(colloquial, impolite, derogatory, potentially offensive) (usually as "old fart") An elderly person; especially one perceived to hold old-fashioned views.

verbs.description: fart (third-person singular simple present farts, present participle farting, simple past and past participle farted)

entries.meaning: (informal, impolite, intransitive) To emit digestive gases from the anus; to flatulate.
examples: Synonyms: beef, blow off, break wind, cut one loose, cut the cheese, flatulate, toot, pass gas, pass wind; see also Thesaurus:flatulate

entries.meaning: (colloquial, intransitive, usually as "fart around") To waste time with idle and inconsequential tasks; to go about one's activities in a lackadaisical manner; to be lazy or over-relaxed in one's manner or bearing.
examples: Synonyms: futz, fool around, fool about
Above his head the funnel farted black soot into the sky.
